Situation1: They maintain daily communication with their parents, sharing detailed updates and responding promptly to messages.
Situation2: Many prospects ask detailed technical questions about the new service that the script only partially addresses.
Story: My phone buzzed for the third time in ten minutes. I glanced at the screen—another message from Mom, asking if I’d eaten lunch and how my morning was going. Normally, I’d reply right away, maybe send a photo of my sandwich or a quick voice note. But right now, I was on a call with a customer who kept firing off technical questions about our new service, questions my script barely covered. My supervisor’s words echoed in my head: “Don’t let them hang up. Handle every objection. Keep them engaged.” I could hear the impatience in the customer’s voice, and I scrambled to sound confident, flipping through the FAQ sheet with one hand while my other thumb hovered over my phone, itching to text Mom back. I felt the pressure mounting—my parents expected me to be present, attentive, and open, while my job demanded focus, quick thinking, and undivided attention. My heart pounded as I tried to juggle both, knowing I was about to let someone down, no matter what I chose.
